instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related research to trace the composed proportions of different apple varieties in formulated purees and predict the quality characteristics of the purees?
Output: In the related research, three types of spectra were used: MIR spectra (Mid-Infrared), NIR spectra (Near-Infrared), and a combination of both (Vis-NIRS).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related research to trace the composed proportions of different apple varieties in formulated purees and predict the quality characteristics of the purees?
Output: Standard normal variate (SNV) pre-processing, resampling, and derivative transform calculation (Savitzky–Golay method) were used in the research to trace the composed proportions of different apple varieties in formulated purees and predict the quality characteristics of the purees.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the models' performance in the related research to trace the composed proportions of different apple varieties in formulated purees and predict the quality characteristics of the purees and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the models' performance in the related study was the Root Mean Square Error of Prediction (RMSEP) and the Residual Prediction Deviation (RPD). The RMSEP was used to assess the accuracy of the models in estimating the proportions of each apple cultivar in puree mixtures, with a value of less than 8.1% considered acceptable. The RPD was used to evaluate the models' ability to predict the quality characteristics of the formulated purees, with values greater than 3.6 indicating good predictive ability.

The text does not provide information on how far this metric can go in terms of its upper limit or maximum value.

instruction: Can the PLS models using MIR spectra be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating the proportions of apple cultivars in puree mixtures?
Output: Yes, the PLS models using MIR spectra can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately estimating the proportions of apple cultivars in puree mixtures. The PLS models were able to estimate the proportions of each apple cultivar in puree mixtures with a high level of accuracy, as indicated by the low root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) values (less than 8.1%) and high ratio of performance to deviation (RPD) values (greater than 3.6). Specifically, the PLS models performed exceptionally well in estimating the proportions of Granny Smith cultivar (RMSEP = 2.7%, RPD = 11.4).
